messages.text: <https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node#3160-protocol-600-json-rpc-700-client-and-700-server> probably somehow explains what is going on, but I don't get it from a first read...

elements.text: probably somehow explains what is going on, but I don't get it from a first read...

messages.text: Actually, I think passing the value just as a value in `params` is not legal under json rpc: <https://www.jsonrpc.org/specification#parameter_structures>

elements.text: Actually, I think passing the value just as a value in
params
is not legal under json rpc:

messages.text: And the new version of the JSON RPC client library now seems to properly pass this as a by-position structure.

elements.text: And the new version of the JSON RPC client library now seems to properly pass this as a by-position structure.

messages.text: Makes sense

elements.text: Makes sense

messages.text: So I probably need to update JSONRPC.jl to match that story

messages.text: This was a lot more work than I thought :slightly_smiling_face: But I think I'm pretty much done. These are a fair number of PRs across many repos. I think I'm going to merge all of these right away, because at the moment really pretty much everything is completely broken. BUT, it would be great if you guys could review these PRs after the fact, and if you spot anything that looks wrong we can try to fix it with follow-up PRs.

messages.text: <@U6A7NFP62> not sure I understand the proposal fully :slightly_smiling_face: I think the problem with an `eval` is that we probably can't combine that with the `includet`  mechanism? But I think I overall don't fully understand the idea, i.e. why one would want to eval into `Test` .

elements.text: not sure I understand the proposal fully
I think the problem with an
eval
is that we probably can't combine that with the
includet
mechanism? But I think I overall don't fully understand the idea, i.e. why one would want to eval into
Test

messages.text: ```eval(Test, :(macro testset(args...) first(args) in list_of_testsets_to_exclude ? :nothing : normal_testset_macro end))```

elements.text: eval(Test, :(macro testset(args...) first(args) in list_of_testsets_to_exclude ? :nothing : normal_testset_macro end))

messages.text: i.e. can we use `Test` and replace what `@testset` means before running the tests?

elements.text: i.e. can we use `Test` and replace what
@testset
means before running the tests?

messages.text: Ah, got it! I don't know, tbh :slightly_smiling_face: It seems very brittle, because in general my sense is that `@testset` is not designed for fine grained run control. `@testset` have no requirement to run by themselves, it seems perfectly legal to have complicated dependency structures inside a `runtests.jl` file that make any attempt to run partial `@testset` things fail.

elements.text: Ah, got it! I don't know, tbh
It seems very brittle, because in general my sense is that
@testset
is not designed for fine grained run control.
@testset
have no requirement to run by themselves, it seems perfectly legal to have complicated dependency structures inside a
runtests.jl
file that make any attempt to run partial
@testset
things fail.

messages.text: I think really if we wanted fine grained test run control, we would need a different unit testing framework for that...

elements.text: I think really if we wanted fine grained test run control, we would need a different unit testing framework for that...

messages.text: So my sense is that for live testing just having a different entry file seems the most stable thing. Essentially that just means users can structure their tests however they want, including in a way that works well with live testing.

elements.text: So my sense is that for live testing just having a different entry file seems the most stable thing. Essentially that just means users can structure their tests however they want, including in a way that works well with live testing.

messages.text: I think for running subsets of tests, really something like <https://github.com/RelationalAI-oss/XUnit.jl> is needed...

elements.text: I think for running subsets of tests, really something like
is needed...

messages.text: That all makes sense, I think I've always written things on the assumption that each test set was isolated from all others apart from enclosing parent ones

elements.text: That all makes sense, I think I've always written things on the assumption that each test set was isolated from all others apart from enclosing parent ones

messages.text: it would be really nice to be able to run them in isolation though

elements.text: it would be really nice to be able to run them in isolation though

messages.text: Yes, totally agree. I think we could consider adding explicit support for another testing framework that actually provides that level of detail, like XUnit.jl, though?

elements.text: Yes, totally agree. I think we could consider adding explicit support for another testing framework that actually provides that level of detail, like XUnit.jl, though?

attachments.title: Enhanced autocompletion in Julia, R and Python (LSP)
attachments.text: With gradual progress jupyterlab-lsp arrived at a place when we can show off this simple gif with an LSP-driven autocompletion working across Julia, Python and R: It’s a small thing, but hopefully will make the user-experience better. I hope to submit a JEP pre-proposal to make it an official Jupyter subproject soon :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text: I've am also trying to figure out what is going on with the crash reports from the extension side of things. BUT, somehow we lost our nice stack traces for those, and now only get the line number in the bundled javascript file of things, which is completely useless (because _everything_ in the bundle is on line 1)... Not I'm pretty positive we had nice filenames and line numbers in those crash reports in the past, so I think something must be broken with our source maps now.
